title: Start by Using Gibbs Free Energy Equation
text: To find the temperature at which this reaction becomes non-spontaneous, you can use the Gibbs Free Energy equation:\n$$G=H-T$$ × S.

title: Understand the Necessary Conditions
text: A reaction becomes non-spontaneous when the Gibbs Free Energy, G, becomes non-negative (greater than 0).\nTherefore, set $$G=0$$ and solve for T.

title: Relate Gibbs Equation to Equilibrium
text: For $$G=0$$, the equation simplifies to:\n$$0=H-T$$ × S.\nRearrrange the equation to find T.

title: Make Rearrangements to Isolate T
text: Isolate T by rearranging the equation:\n$$T=\frac{H}{S}$$

title: Perform Calculation to Determine T
text: Use the known values, $$∆G=$$ $$-33.30$$ $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ and ∆H(which is ∆H°_f) $$=$$ $$-45.90$$ $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$, and substitute them into the equation:\nT=∆H/∆S\nFirst, calculate ∆S using ∆G $$=$$ ∆H-T × ∆S.

title: Calculate the Gibbs at Equilibrium
text: Calculate ∆S by setting ∆G ≈ $$0$$ at the equilibrium temperature to find the equation:\n$$0=∆H-T$$ × ∆S

title: Find ∆S and Solve for T
text: After rearranging to solve for ∆S:\n∆S=∆H/T\nUse $$∆H=\frac{-45.9kJ}{mol}$$ and the provided equilibrium condition to estimate when $$∆H=\frac{-33.3kJ}{mol}$$.

title: Substitute Values & Calculate Temperature
text: After finding ∆S, take the temperature value, convert to Kelvin if needed, and input into the equation:\nT=∆H/∆S,\nwhich provides the temperature at which the reaction becomes non-spontaneous.
